contents.literal:
Adding your first network
All cities will be added via an Rest API called PositionStack. So, when you press 'run', it is indeed fetching an query on that api. 

By name
Add the city name you want to add, press run. 

By country
Add the country name you want to fetch cities, add the quantity of cities, press run. 

By limit
Add the quantity of cities you want to fetch, press run. 

Deleting nodes
You can either delete all, or click with the right button on any node and delete it. 

In a rush?
No time to use the api call and still want to compare the solves? In the Data Manager you will find a few ready to analyse scenarios!

Run differences
Run all
This will run all 3 heuristics without iterations. This run will be important when comparing execution time. 

Initial solution
This will run the initial tour.

Improved simultaneous
This will run the improved simultaneous tour with iteractions. It can take a while. You will not be able to stop the run without closing the system. 

Improved cyclic
This will run the improved cyclic tour with iteractions. It can take a while. You will not be able to stop the run without closing the system. 

Understanting the colors
Pink
If the nodes are pink, the run is completed.

Orange
The system is still running the iteractions please wait.

Models
MIP without subtours
This is a MIP model without considering subtours. 

MIP may contain subtours
This is useful to understand the lowest bound and feasible solution. As the name say, this may contain subtours.

Story 

The Traveling Salesman Problem (TSP) is the problem of finding the shortest route visiting all cities precisely once. Given are the distances between the cities.
 
TSP problems are widely studied in the scientific literature because:
  • they are notoriously difficult to solve to optimality (NP-Hard),
  • there is a wide range of applications, and
  • there are various approaches of solving the problem.
 
This example is structured as follows:
  • The page "Network" permits you define your own network.
You can use the data manager (icon data manager) to save and load instances. Two cases come with this example.
Distances are estimated using the Haversine formula.

  • The page "Heuristic" illustrates three different heuristics to solve a TSP.

  • The page "Exact" shows how a MIP can be used to solve a TSP.

  • The page "Comparison" compare total distance and execution time for each solve.
 
Each of the above pages comes with a HELP side-panel, explaining how to operate that page.

Welcome!

You are in an AIMMS Example. Feel free to play around and create something more in this app!
 
If you do, please fork this repository and commit your changes. This ensures our GitHub stays up-to-date for the entire community!

You can also check our other interactive resources:

  • In the Online Community, talk to other developers and AIMMSians about the product, modeling, use cases, and more.
  • In the Academy, learn new skills and challenge yourself. We are busy creating new courses, so keep an eye out!

For questions that can't be posted on the community, contact us at support@aimms.com.
